title: Comprehensive Validation Report for Asteroid Lightcurve Inversion Pipeline
description: Complete validation report covering per-asteroid metrics for ground-truth tests, benchmark comparison against published tools (MPO LCInvert, SAGE, KOALA/ADAM), optimization log with parameter strategies, sparse vs. dense performance comparison, candidate inversion summary, and summary statistics across all tested asteroids.

433_Eros.notes: Period within candidate set at 0.003% but best-fit from joint optimization drifted to 0.6%. Pole error significant, likely due to coarse pole grid search and limited apparition coverage in ALCDEF subset.

216_Kleopatra.ground_truth_source: Radar + AO (Shepard et al. 2018, Descamps et al. 2011)
216_Kleopatra.notes: Kleopatra's extreme bilobed shape violates convex assumption severely. Solver did not converge. Pole error large, likely due to non-convex geometry confounding the convex model.

25143_Itokawa.notes: Best overall result. Near-south-pole retrograde rotator where longitude is degenerate. 22.8 deg pole error reasonable given only 3 lightcurve sessions. Period recovery excellent at 0.064%.

comparison_table.description: Our pipeline results compared against published results from MPO LCInvert (convex inversion), SAGE (Bartczak & Dudzinski 2018), and KOALA/ADAM (Carry 2012, Viikinkoski 2015). Values drawn from benchmark_comparison.json.

metrics.assessment: Our pipeline achieves 0.06-0.6% period accuracy, 1-2 orders of magnitude worse than convex inversion with larger datasets. Itokawa result (0.064%) from only 3 sessions is promising.
Our pole accuracy (23-69 deg) is significantly worse than established tools (2-10 deg). Primary area needing improvement. Gap partly explained by 3-7x less data.

SAGE.433_Eros: high visual agreement with NEAR shape

KOALA_ADAM.216_Kleopatra: detailed bilobed model (55 LCs + 14 AO + 3 occultations)

metrics.assessment: Direct IoU comparison not possible due to inconsistent metrics across tools. Our IoU values (0.19-0.34) are moderate, partly limited by triaxial ellipsoid ground-truth approximations.
Our residual RMS (0.08-0.10 mag) is 3-5x higher than established tools (0.01-0.03 mag). Indicates room for improvement in forward model fidelity and scattering law.
Our pipeline used 3-7x less data than published studies. This data volume gap is a critical confounding factor in accuracy comparisons.

optimization_log.description: Parameter strategies attempted during the adaptive regularization loop for blind validation. Each ground-truth asteroid was tested with multiple pole trial initializations. The optimizer ran an L-BFGS-B minimization from each pole seed, recording chi2, RMS, and convergence status. This documents the pole-grid search and adaptive approach used (item_015).
optimization_log.methodology: For each asteroid, period was first determined via Lomb-Scargle periodogram with chi-squared refinement. Then 2-4 pole initializations were tested, each running full convex shape inversion with L-BFGS-B optimizer. The best chi2 solution was selected. Adaptive regularization (item_015) iterated over smoothness weights and facet counts to minimize residuals.

period_search.note: True period found in candidate set at 0.003% error; joint optimization drifted to 0.6%

pole_trials.note: Close to trial 1 solution, slightly higher chi2

period_search.note: Period search identified correct neighborhood; joint optimization shifted by 0.234%

pole_trials.note: Initialized near true pole; chi2 higher due to convex model inadequacy for bilobed shape
Worst fit; far from optimal pole region

period_search.note: Excellent period recovery from only 3 sessions (211 data points)

pole_trials.note: Best chi2; pole migrated toward high latitude as expected for near-pole rotator
Initialized near true pole latitude; converged to similar high-latitude solution

optimization_log.adaptive_regularization_notes: The adaptive loop (item_015) tested 10 parameter strategies varying lambda_smooth (0.001 to 1.0), n_facets (100 to 500), and max_iterations (5 to 50). For all three ground-truth asteroids, the IoU remained below the 95% convergence threshold due to fundamental limitations: triaxial ellipsoid ground-truth approximations, limited ALCDEF data coverage, and convex model inadequacy for non-convex targets (Kleopatra, Itokawa). The loop correctly documented failure analysis attributing shortfalls to data volume and model expressiveness rather than regularization tuning alone.

sparse_vs_dense.description: Comparison of dense vs. sparse photometric inversion from sparse_experiment_results.json. Dense inversions used full ALCDEF lightcurve data; sparse inversions subsampled to 100-150 points from 3 simulated apparitions.

experiment_setup.method: L-BFGS-B convex inversion applied to both data modes

summary.conclusion: Dense photometry provides dramatically better period recovery (<0.3% error) compared to sparse survey-like data (14-65% errors). Sparse inversion struggles with limited geometric coverage, consistent with findings from Durech et al. (2009). The dense-to-sparse degradation ranges from 14 to 65 percentage points in period error and 45 to 53 degrees in pole difference. This demonstrates the clear value of dense ALCDEF lightcurves over survey-quality sparse data for lightcurve inversion.

candidate_summary.description: Summary of candidate asteroid inversions from candidate_inversion_results.json. These are newly modeled asteroids not in the DAMIT database.

summary_statistics.description: Aggregate statistics across all ground-truth validation asteroids and candidate inversions.

all_modeled_asteroids.description: Statistics across all 8 asteroids (3 ground-truth + 5 candidates)

references.citation: Kaasalainen, M., Torppa, J. & Muinonen, K. (2001). Optimization Methods for Asteroid Lightcurve Inversion. II. The Complete Inverse Problem. Icarus, 153, 37-51.
references.relevance: Foundational convex inversion method used as basis for our pipeline's forward model and chi-squared optimization.

references.citation: Bartczak, P. & Dudzinski, G. (2018). Shaping asteroid models using genetic evolution (SAGE). MNRAS, 473, 5050-5065.
references.relevance: Primary reference for non-convex genetic algorithm approach. Validated on Eros: pole (17, 8) +/- 5 deg. Our GA module is SAGE-inspired.

references.citation: Durech, J., Sidorin, V. & Kaasalainen, M. (2010). DAMIT: a database of asteroid models. A&A, 513, A46.
references.relevance: DAMIT database with 5700+ convex models providing reference pole/period values and context for our comparison table.

references.citation: Viikinkoski, M., Kaasalainen, M. & Durech, J. (2015). ADAM: a general method for using various data types in asteroid reconstruction. A&A, 576, A8.
references.relevance: Multi-modal fusion framework. Applied to Kleopatra with 55 LCs + AO + occultations. Our hybrid dense+sparse module follows ADAM principles.

references.citation: Carry, B. et al. (2012). Shape modeling technique KOALA validated by ESA Rosetta at (21) Lutetia. PSS, 66, 200-212.
references.relevance: KOALA validation: pole accuracy 2 deg, dimension accuracy 2% vs Rosetta ground truth. Provides gold-standard benchmark for shape modeling pipelines.

references.citation: Durech, J. et al. (2009). Asteroid models from combined sparse and dense photometry. A&A, 493, 291-297.
references.relevance: Methodology for sparse+dense data combination. Our sparse experiment results are consistent with their finding that sparse data alone is insufficient for reliable inversion.

references.citation: Warner, B.D., Harris, A.W. & Pravec, P. (2009). The asteroid lightcurve database. Icarus, 202, 134-146.
references.relevance: MPO LCInvert software reference. 315-point pole grid search used as comparison baseline for our pipeline's pole search resolution.

references.citation: Hanus, J. et al. (2011). A study of asteroid pole-latitude distribution based on an extended set of shape models. A&A, 530, A134.
references.relevance: Typical pole uncertainty ~10 deg for dense-data convex inversion models. Provides statistical context for our pole error results.

strengths: Period recovery is the pipeline's strongest capability: 0.064% for Itokawa (3 sessions), 0.234% for Kleopatra, 0.608% for Eros.
Fully automated end-to-end pipeline requiring no manual intervention, unlike MPO LCInvert's wizard-based workflow.
GA-based non-convex refinement provides capability that MPO LCInvert lacks entirely.
Able to produce results from as few as 3 lightcurve sessions (Itokawa), valuable for asteroids with limited ALCDEF coverage.
5 new candidate asteroid models produced (Anteros, Heracles, Florence, Didymos, Wilson-Harrington), none previously in DAMIT.
weaknesses: Pole accuracy (23-69 deg) is 3-10x worse than established tools (2-10 deg). Highest priority for improvement.
Lightcurve fit residuals (0.08-0.10 mag) are 3-5x higher than convex inversion tools (0.01-0.03 mag).
Shape IoU values (0.19-0.34) are moderate, though partly limited by triaxial ellipsoid ground-truth approximations.
Only 50% of models converged (4/8), suggesting optimization robustness needs improvement.
Sparse data inversion shows severe degradation (14-65% period errors), limiting applicability to survey-quality photometry.
recommended_improvements: Increase pole grid resolution to 315+ points matching MPO LCInvert.
Implement two-stage optimization: fix period, then optimize pole on fine grid, then jointly refine.
Add Hapke scattering law with opposition effect for better phase angle modeling.
Compute exact Sun-asteroid-observer vectors from orbital elements rather than PAB approximation.
Obtain actual DAMIT/spacecraft shape models for proper IoU comparison.
Increase GA population size and generations for non-convex refinement.
